              1.      INTRODUCTION & BACKGROUND
The Lakeview Waterfront Connection (LWC) project is one of several revitalization projects and
activities that are being undertaken within the southeast Mississauga waterfront area. The LWC
Project aims to create coastal and terrestrial habitats to improve ecological function and create
an accessible waterfront area for the residents of Mississauga.

This report examines the traffic and parking-related impacts of the proposed development by
considering a number of horizons, including construction periods.


1.1    Study Area
The immediate study area for this project is illustrated in Figure 1, and includes a portion of
Marie Curtis Park, the Lakeview Water Treatment Plant, Lakeview Park, the Mississauga Sailing
Club, and several additional parks adjacent to the waterfront.

In addition to the immediate area in close vicinity to the proposed waterfront connection, a larger
study area was considered for assessing traffic impacts. This is useful for the construction
horizons when clean fill is expected to be brought in from areas all over the Region of Peel.




                                Figure 1 – Study Area & Project Limits




                                                                                                 1|P a g e
1.2        Traffic Data
The traffic data for this project was provided by the City of Mississauga, Region of Peel, the City
of Toronto, and the Ministry of Transportation of Ontario (MTO). A summary of the data is
included in Table 1. In addition to the traffic counts, signal timing plans were also provided for
major intersections within the study area. Traffic data is included in Appendix A.

1.3    Study Horizons
This study considers 5 horizons, as depicted in Figure 2. For each horizon, traffic volumes were
determined and traffic analysis was carried out.


            • Existing Conditions

  2013        • Growth in background traffic from existing counts to 2013

            • Start of Construction
              • Growth in background traffic from existing counts to 2014
  2014        • Truck traffic generated by the site

            • End of Construction
              • Growth in background traffic from existing counts to 2022
  2022        • Truck traffic generated by the site

            • Project Open (5-
                           (5-Year Horizon)
              • Growth in background traffic from existing counts to 2027
  2027        • Visitor traffic generated by the site

            • Project Open (10-
                           (10-Year Horizon)
              • Growth in background traffic from existing counts to 2032
  2032        • Visitor traffic generated by the site


                                              Figure 2 - Study Horizons

Note that diagrams illustrating the traffic volumes for each study horizon are included in
Appendix B.


1.4    Analysis & Modeling Assumptions
The traffic operations analysis was completed using the Synchro 7 software suite. Synchro was
used to determine level of service (LOS) and volume-to-capacity (V/C) ratios while SimTraffic
was used to observe and confirm the findings of Synchro. SimTraffic is traffic signal optimization
based micro-simulation software; as such, it models the actual traffic operations on the coded
network and takes various measurements during the simulation including queues and delays.
Synchro results are provided in Appendix C. Modeling assumptions are summarized below:




                                                                                                3|P a g e
          0.5% traffic growth rate - The growth rate was established based on data made available
          through the Region of Peel’s Open Data Program1. An analysis based on 10 years of
          historical data on the major streets within the study area revealed that most AADTs
          declined, so a +0.5% growth rate is a conservative assumption.

          Existing signal timing plans were used for the existing conditions analysis, while future
          horizons used optimized plans for congested intersections

          Peak Hour Factor (PHF) = 0.95 (However, a PHF of 1.00 was used in SimTraffic for very
          congested conditions)

When interpreting the model results, it is important to understand the LOS definitions employed
for this report. Level of Service is a concept which is used to quantify travel conditions along a
given corridor or intersection. For vehicular travel along a roadway, LOS ‘A’ is indicative of free
flow conditions and LOS ‘F’ is indicative of congested conditions (refer to Figure 3). LOS ‘F’
typically corresponds to a volume-to-capacity ratio > 1.0, or delay > 80.0 seconds, and is often
used as a threshold for identifying the need for improvements.

    LOS A              LOS B              LOS C              LOS D              LOS E          LOS F




                                    Figure 3 – The Level of Service Concept




1
    http://opendata.peelregion.ca/data-categories/transportation/traffic-count-stations.aspx



                                                                                                       4|P a g e
                           2.        EXISTING CONDITIONS
This section of the report provides a baseline analysis by evaluating present-day conditions.
While both construction and site traffic may place additional strain on the road network, it is
important to understand how the network operates at present in order to determine what level of
mitigation (if any) is required in the future as a result of the project.


2.1    Existing Conditions (2013)

             • Existing Conditions

  2013         • Growth in background traffic from existing counts to 2013



Since the site does not exist at present, the existing conditions at major intersections
surrounding the site were assessed to provide a benchmark. The results for the morning (AM)
peak hour (refer to Table 2) indicate that there are intersections at present which operate at
unfavourable conditions. There are also intersections with failing approaches in the afternoon
(PM) peak hour (refer to Table 3).

In particular, the following intersections have approaches with LOS of ‘F’:
       Erin Mills / North Sheridan Way (AM, PM)
       Erin Mill / South Sheridan Way (AM, PM)
       Lakeshore / Mississauga (AM)
       Lakeshore / Hurontario (PM)
       Cawthra / Atwater (AM)
       Cawthra / South Service Road (AM,PM)
       Cawthra / North Service Road (AM,PM)
       Cawthra / South Ramp Terminal (PM)
       Lakeshore / Brown’s Line Northbound (AM)

Note that the critical movements are those with V/C ≥ 0.9 or delay ≥ 80.0 seconds. The V/C and
delay, respectively, are shown in the brackets following the movement.

2.2    Existing Transit Services
Based on a review of background information including “Inspiration Lakeview Phase 1
Background Report (Draft, Nov 2010),” it was found that the study area is currently served by
regional transit (GO) and local transit (TTC and Mississauga). There are a number of transit
routes in and around the study area, based on the Inspiration Lakeview study, including:
    • Mississauga Transit Route 5 serves Lakeshore Road E. from Ogden Avenue to the Long
        Branch GO Station (10 minute headways during peak hours);
    • Mississauga Route 23 serves Lakeshore Road E. (16 minute headways during peak
        hours);
    • No bus service on Cawthra;
    • GO Transit Stations near Lakeview are accessible via Route 5 (Long Branch) and Route
        23 (Port Credit and Long Branch); and,
    • Connections can be made at Long Branch GO Station to many TTC bus lines.



                                                                                               8|P a g e
                                3.     CONSTRUCTION PHASE
3.1                 Truck Traffic
During the construction period, trucks will be carrying fill from all over Peel Region to the site to
provide construction materials. It is recognized that fill material may come from other sources
such as the City of Toronto; however, it was assumed that the majority would come from the
Peel region. Since about 250 total trucks will arrive at the site everyday (known quantity), the
origin of these trips was estimated proportionally using the percentage of total fill produced by
each ward in the Peel Region (refer to Table 4). This approach assumes fill production rates by
each ward will be similar in the future.
                                Table 4 – Distribution of Trips based on Fill Production

                         Zone                Fill (m3)                Percentage Daily Trips Peak Hour
                         M1                  150,020                       10%             24     4
                         M2                   62,541                        4%             10     2
                         M3                  184,477                       12%             30     5
                         M4                   12,919                        1%              2     0
      Mississauga




                         M5                  212,822                       14%             34     5
                         M6                   5,826                        0%               1     0
                         M7                   37,289                        2%              6     1
                         M8                   27,778                        2%              4     1
                         M9                   33,577                        2%              5     1
                        M10                   2,925                        0%               0     0
                        M11                   29,452                        2%              5     1
                         B1                   17,061                        1%              3     0
                         B2                   26,547                        2%              4     1
                         B3                   31,180                        2%              5     1
                         B4                   3,481                        0%               1     0
      Brampton




                         B5                   5,007                        0%               1     0
                         B6                  221,791                       14%             36     6
                         B7                   5,507                        0%               1     0
                         B8                   55,101                        4%              9     1
                         B9                   9,696                        1%               2     0

                         C1                       -                        0%               0    0
      Caledon




                         C2                  240,241                      15%              39     6
                         C3                       -                        0%               0    0
                         C4                   6,798                        0%               1     0
                         C5                   54,046                        3%              9     1
                    TOTAL                   1,552,242                     100%             250   40




                                                                                                      9|P a g e
Once the number of trips from each ward was determined, they were routed to the project site in
order to determine which intersections will experience an increase in truck traffic. The truck
traffic from each ward was routed from the centroid (refer to Figure 4) to the intersection of Dixie
& Lakeshore, which was considered to be the primary access route for construction purposes.
Routing generally followed the route with the fastest travel time. In some places, a combination
of routes was considered in order to be most conservative.




                  Figure 4 – Wards in Peel Region (Caledon, Brampton, & Mississauga)



                                                                                                 10 | P a g e
3.2    Start of Construction (2014)

             • Start of Construction
               • Growth in background traffic from existing counts to 2014
  2014         • Truck traffic generated by the site



By 2014, trucks will begin arriving at the site. Volumes corresponding to the start of construction
were analyzed for the AM peak hour (Table 5) and PM peak hour (Table 6).

The intersections with approaches at LOS of ‘F’ have been identified below.
Intersections/periods which did not experience failure in the existing conditions analysis are
shown in red, while intersections/periods that no longer experience failure compared to existing
conditions are crossed out:
       Erin Mills / North Sheridan Way (AM, PM)
       Erin Mill / South Sheridan Way (AM, PM)
       Lakeshore / Southdown (PM)
       Lakeshore / Mississauga (AM)
       Lakeshore / Hurontario (PM)
       Cawthra / Atwater (AM)
       Cawthra / South Service Road (AM,PM)
       Cawthra / North Service Road (AM,PM)
       Cawthra / South Ramp Terminal (PM)
       Lakeshore / Brown’s Line Northbound (AM)

It is clear from these conditions that there has not been a significant change in conditions as
result of the construction traffic. The majority of intersections with approaches at LOS of ‘F’ have
remained at that LOS. The Lakeshore/Southdown intersection during the PM peak is a newly
marked approach with an LOS of ‘F’; this is because the EB approach was already at a LOS of
‘E’ in 2013. The intersection of Lakeshore/Mississauga was improved from its LOS of F in 2013
by optimizing the signal timing plan. In some cases, it was actually possible to improve
conditions through variations on signal timing plans.

3.3    End of Construction (2022)


            • End of Construction
              • Growth in background traffic from existing counts to 2022
  2022        • Truck traffic generated by the site



Volumes corresponding to the end of construction were investigated. The results are illustrated
in Table 7 for the AM peak hour and in Table 8 in the PM peak hour.

The intersections with approaches at LOS of ‘F’ have been identified below.
Intersections/periods which did not experience failure in the existing conditions analysis are
shown in red.
       Erin Mills / North Sheridan Way (AM, PM)
       Erin Mill / South Sheridan Way (AM, PM)
       Lakeshore / Southdown (PM)
       Lakeshore / Mississauga (AM)
       Lakeshore / Hurontario (PM)
       Cawthra / Atwater (AM)
       Cawthra / South Service Road (AM,PM)
       Cawthra / North Service Road (AM,PM)
       Cawthra / South Ramp Terminal (PM)
       Dixie / Sherway (PM)
       Lakeshore / Brown’s Line Northbound (AM)

It is clear from these conditions that there has not been a significant change in conditions as
result of the construction traffic. The Lakeshore / Southdown intersection was already at the
LOS of ‘F’ in 2014, and given 8 years of traffic increases, it remained at the LOS of ‘F’. The
Dixie / Sherway intersection during the PM peak is a newly marked approach with an LOS of ‘F’;
this is because the SB approach was already at a LOS of ‘E’ in 2014. Given 8 years of increase
in traffic, it is expected that this intersection would pass the threshold and be experiencing an
LOS of ‘F’.

                                                         18 | P a g e
                            4.       POST-CONSTRUCTION
4.1     Site-Generated Traffic
In order to determine the site-generated traffic, a number of potentially relevant land-use types
from the ITE Trip Generation Manual were considered. The ITE Trip Generation Manual uses
sample data collected from similar land uses in the United States to generate the expected
number of trips created by future developments. A summary of these is provided below:

        411 City Park – City parks are owned and operated by a city. The city parks surveyed
        varied widely as to location, type, and number of facilities, including boating or swimming
        facilities, ball fields, camp sites, picnic facilities, and general open space. 3 sites
        surveyed between 1970s and 1990s in New Jersey and California.
        412 County Park – County parks are owned and operated by a county. The county
        parks surveyed varied widely as to location, type, and number of facilities, including
        boating or swimming facilities, ball fields, camp sites, picnic facilities, and general open
        space. 6-7 sites surveyed between 1970s and 1990s in New Jersey and California.
        414 Water Slide Park – Water slide parks contain water slides, wading pools,
        refreshment stands and picnic areas. Sample consisted of only 1 site in Idaho.
        415 Beach Park – Beach parks consist of a beach and possibly other facilities such as
        changing rooms, restrooms, picnic facilities, and hiking, fishing and camping facilities. 6
        sites from San Francisco and California.
        420 Marina - Marinas are public or private facilities that provide docks and berths for
        boats and may include limited retail and restaurant space. Sites from metropolitan areas
        of San Francisco, San Diego and Seattle.
                               th
Information extracted from the 6 edition Trip Generation Manual, ITE

Based on these descriptions and the relevance / sample size, it was determined that the two
most relevant types were 415 Beach Park and 411 City Park. These land-use types should
encompass all activities expected to occur at the Lakeview Waterfront Connection, including but
not limited to recreational activities such as bird watching, dog walking, angling, kayaking, kite-
boarding etc. The approximate areas of each land-use type were assigned to three categories
and multiplied by trip rates in order to determine future trip generation:
                                        Table 9 – Site Generated Traffic
                  Approximate              Trip Generation
   Type                                                                AM Peak Trips   PM Peak Trips
               Percentage of Area             Category
                                                                           4 (IN)          3 (IN)
  Beach                 15%                Beach Park (415)
                                                                          3 (OUT)         5 (OUT)
 Wetland                15%                      None                        --              --
                                                                           7 (IN)          7 (IN)
 Meadow                 70%                 City Park (411)
                                                                          7 (OUT)         7 (OUT)
                                                                          11 (IN)         10 (IN)
  TOTAL                100%                         --
                                                                         10 (OUT)        12 (OUT)



                                                                                                       19 | P a g e
It is important to note that although the peak hour of trip generation for the project is not likely to
coincide with the AM and PM peak hours on the adjacent road network, it is important to use
these as the starting point since they are critical in terms of overall traffic on the network. While
the trip rates may seems low, it should be kept in mind that peak trip production for the
development is likely to be either weekday evenings, or more probably, during the weekends.
However, both of these time periods represent “off-peak” conditions, so the increase in site-
generated traffic will be less likely to cause problems than those occurring at the busiest part of
the day (AM & PM peak hours).


4.2    Future Transit Improvements
Based on a review of background information including “Inspiration Lakeview Phase 1
Background Report (Draft, Nov 2010),” it was found that there are a number of planned future
transit improvements including, the following.
    • Lakeshore Road from Port Credit GO Station to Union Station has been identified as a
         Regional Rapid Transit route in the 15 Year Plan (Metrolinx);
    • Lakeshore Line corridor infrastructure and service improvement (Metrolinx – GO
         Transit); and,
    • Waterfront West LRT to Long Branch GO Station (TTC).

               • Growth in background traffic from existing counts to 2032

Since the site-generated traffic is not projected to increase, any changes between 2027 and
2032 are due to a growth in background traffic, and are not attributable to the project itself.
Results for the AM peak hour are shown in Table 12, with results for the PM peak hour shown in
Table 13.

The intersections with approaches at LOS of ‘F’ have been identified below.
Intersections/periods which did not experience failure in the existing conditions analysis are
shown in red, while intersections/periods that no longer experience failure compared to existing
conditions are crossed out:
       Erin Mills / North Sheridan Way (AM, PM)
       Erin Mill / South Sheridan Way (AM, PM)
       Lakeshore / Mississauga (AM)
       Lakeshore / Hurontario (PM)
       Cawthra / Atwater (AM)

       Cawthra / North Service Road (AM,PM)
       Cawthra / South Ramp Terminal (AM,PM)
       Dixie / Sherway (PM)
       Lakeshore / Brown’s Line Northbound (AM)

It should be noted that even with almost 20 years of background traffic growth, traffic operations
were observed to be similar to the existing conditions. As such, the project-generated traffic is
not the primary factor affecting traffic conditions.

                                                         27 | P a g e
                           5.     PARKING ANALYSIS
5.1    Existing Conditions
A site visit was conducted to assess parking conditions in the vicinity of the project site. A high-
level, visual assessment of parking capacities and occupancies was carried out on the following
days:

       Thursday July 11th, 2013 – Sunny & hot conditions

       Saturday July 13th, 2013 – Sunny & hot conditions

The location of parking lots surrounding the project site is shown below in Figure 5.




                                   Figure 5 – Parking Lot Locations

Based on findings on site, the following summary of the parking lots was prepared (refer to
Table 14), which indicates high occupancy rates in lots 1, 7, 9, 10 and 11, particularly on the
weekend. This is consistent with the recreational sites served by these developments, which
would be expected to peak on weekends during the daytime.

While these lots have occupancy rates which are greater than 50%, only lots 1 and 7 are of real
concern, since they have occupancies which may encourage illegal parking (such as in Lot 1)
or cause spillover to additional lots or on-street within residential neighbourhoods nearby.




                                                                                                 28 | P a g e
                                      Table 14 – Existing Parking Conditions

  2         100           N/A          60%               20%          + boat trailer parking in the centre of the lot. Boat launch at
                                                                      NE corner of lot

                                                                      south end of lot.




                                                                                                                              29 | P a g e
5.2    Future Conditions
The future parking generation was determined based on the ITE parking generation
guidelines. The land use category which most closely resembles the Lakeview Connection
is #411: City Park. The parking generation guidelines only consider two sites for this land
use category and only apply to Saturdays and Sundays. Since the site investigation of
parking utilization was completed on a Thursday and a Saturday, only the Saturday parking
generations will be considered in this discussion. The parking generations rates range
between 2.3 to 5.1 vehicles per acre. To remain conservative, the 5.1 vehicles per acre rate
was assumed. Based on the approximated area, this results in approximately 66 vehicles
generated on a Saturday afternoon.

There are approximately 1000 parking stalls in the study area that are available to the public
and the approximate utilization during the Saturday site assessment of the parking
conditions was approximately 600 vehicles. As such there are approximately 400 available
spaces in the area, which can easily accommodate the 66 generated vehicles. However, in
the lots closest to the proposed recreational space (Lots #1 and #2) there are only 150
spaces and the current demand is approximately 95 vehicles. The expected future parking
demand for the proposed recreational space is expected to be mainly in lots #1 and #2. As
such, the lots may be over capacity in future conditions since the demand is expected to be
161 vehicles and the supply is only 150 stalls. On the road that links Lakeshore Rd and
parking lot #2, there are 15 street parking stalls which are expected to accommodate the
additional demand that cannot be accommodated in the parking lots themselves. There is
also potential for future development including additional park land as well as other land
uses that will require additional parking supply.




                                                                                           30 | P a g e
                 6.     SUMMARY & CONCLUSIONS
The analysis presented in this report was completed using Synchro / SimTraffic version 7.
The analysis focused on traffic operations during construction of new recreational space in
Lake Ontario south of Mississauga as well as traffic operations after the recreational space
is open to the public. The analysis found that the network is operating at satisfactory levels
with some exceptions. Intersections with failing approaches are indicated in Table 15 below.

                   Table 15 - Summary of Intersections with Failing Approaches
                                   2013         2014          2022          2027       2032
         Intersection
                                AM     PM     AM     PM    AM     PM     AM      PM   AM   PM

 Erin Mills @ N Sheridan Way    ➻      ➻             ➻     ➻      ➻      ➻       ➻    ➻    ➻
 Erin Mills @ S Sheridan Way    ➻      ➻      ➻      ➻     ➻      ➻      ➻       ➻    ➻    ➻
 Lakeshore @ Southdown                                            ➻
 Lakeshore @ Mississauga        ➻                                        ➻            ➻
 Lakeshore @ Hurontario                ➻             ➻            ➻
 Lakeshore @ Cawthra                                                                       ➻
 Cawthra @ Atwater              ➻             ➻            ➻             ➻            ➻
 Cawthra @ S Service Rd         ➻      ➻      ➻      ➻     ➻      ➻      ➻       ➻    ➻    ➻
 Cawthra @ N Service Rd         ➻      ➻             ➻            ➻      ➻       ➻    ➻    ➻
 Cawthra @ NRT
 Cawthra @ SRT                         ➻             ➻            ➻      ➻       ➻    ➻    ➻
 Lakeshore @ Ogden
 Lakeshore @ Dixie
 Dixie @ Sherway                                                                 ➻         ➻
 Lakeshore @ Brown’s Line
 Southboud
 Lakeshore @ Brown’s Line
 Northboud                      ➻             ➻            ➻             ➻            ➻
 Lakeshore @ Thirty Seventh
 Street

Most of the intersections with approach LOF ‘F’ are present in existing conditions and will
continue to deteriorate as background traffic volumes increase. Most of the issues can be
attributed to high traffic volumes on the network roads.

The site generated traffic during construction was found to be very small in the order of 72
vehicles per hour during the peak hours, which had a negligible impact on the traffic
operations in the study area network. The site generated traffic during the operations of the
recreational space was also found to be very low, in the order of 20 vehicles per hour; with
even less impact on the study area network.

The parking generated by the site is expected to be accommodated in the existing local
parking lots; however, if large special events are planned to be held on the proposed



                                                                                              31 | P a g e
recreational space parking demand may exceed the supply and consideration would have to
be given to the construction of a new parking lot near the new recreational space.
